review.title: Improving Performance Of English-Hindi Cross Language Information Retrieval Using Transliteration Of Query Terms
review.abstract: The main issue in Cross Language Information Retrieval (CLIR) is the poor performance of retrieval in terms of average precision when compared to monolingual retrieval performance. The main reasons behind poor performance of CLIR are mismatching of query terms, lexical ambiguity and un-translated query terms. The existing problems of CLIR are needed to be addressed in order to increase the performance of the CLIR system. In this paper, we are putting our effort to solve the given problem by proposed an algorithm for improving the performance of English-Hindi CLIR system. We used all possible combination of Hindi translated query using transliteration of English query terms and choosing the best query among them for retrieval of documents. The experiment is performed on FIRE 2010 (Forum of Information Retrieval Evaluation) datasets. The experimental result show that the proposed approach gives better performance of English-Hindi CLIR system and also helps in overcoming existing problems and outperforms the existing English-Hindi CLIR system in terms of average precision.

sections.text: DOI: 10.5121 / ijnlc.2013.2604 53The main problem with Cross Language Information Retrieval (CLIR) is the poor performance of the query in terms of average precision compared to the monolingual query. The main reasons for the poor performance of CLIR are the mismatch of query terms, lexical ambiguity and untranslated query terms. The existing problems of CLIR must be addressed in order to improve the performance of the CLIR system. In this paper, we seek to solve the problem by proposing an algorithm to improve the performance of the Anglo-Hindi CLIR system. We have used all possible combinations of Hindi queries using the translation of English query terms and selecting the best query among them to retrieve documents. The experiment is conducted on the basis of FIRE 2010 (Forum of Information Retrieval Evaluation).

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: We are building the broad network architecture for transmitting information across national barriers, but there is still a long way to go before linguistic boundaries can be as effective as geographical [1]. Today, people are more interested in global things such as education, business, business, marketing, research, etc., because people are interested in collecting information and data from other regions of the world, the only medium for this is the Internet. But we also know that users are more likely to access information in a language where a user is more comfortable, or we can say that the user wants information in his / her mother tongue in order to understand the language of the documents more easily. Access to information in a host language is clearly important for many users. In India, about 70% of people know Hindi as their primary language, while we are based on the Human Development Study in 2012; there are only 10.35% people in India who are English-speaking. India is the third country that has the largest number of Internet users, but when we talk about penetration, it means 166% of the total population in India.

sections.heading: 2. RELATED WORK
sections.text: The different approaches to retrieving information from the CLIR system have some advantages and disadvantages. Lisa, et al. [3] proposed in 1998 a method for solving ambiguities in query translation and phrasal translation by using statistical parallel event analysis from unlinked corpus and combining this technique with other techniques for solving ambiguities. KyungSoon al. [4] in 2002 proposed a method for implicitly solving ambiguities in the Korean-English CLIR database, and the author also compared their method with machine translation and parallel corpus techniques and proved that good performance of query can be achieved without the use of complex resources.

sections.heading: 3. PROPOSED METHODOLOGY
sections.text: The system that records user queries in one language and retrieves relevant documents in another is known as the "cross language information retrieval system." Studies say that the performance of CLIR is still low compared to the terms of CLIR such as query expansion, co-occurrence statistics, clustering, etc., but still the performance of English-Hindi CLIR is not as good as that of monolingual IR performance. The most common reasons behind the poor performance of CLIR are: • Lack of availability of resources such as bilingual dictionary, mismatching of out of vocabulary (OOV) terms, stemmer, part of speech (POS) tagger, etc. • Multiple representations of query words (Lexical Ambiguity).

sections.heading: 3.1. Query Translation
sections.text: Translating queries from one language to another is known as query translation. Query translation is a crucial step in the CLIR system because all problems arise from this step, such as query terms, ambiguities, poor query performance, etc. There are various approaches to translating user queries such as bilingual dictionary, parallel corpus, online translators, etc. In this essay, we have used "Shabdanjali" Multi-lingual Readable Dictionary as a lexicon resource for translating English to Hindi Query. The dictionary was developed in IIT Hyderabad. This dictionary is available in ISCII conversion, so a conversion from ISCII to UTF8 encoding code is required.

sections.heading: 4. EXPERIMENTS
sections.text: The experiment is conducted on the basis of FIRE (Forum of Information Retrieval Evaluation) 2010 datasets. FIRE 2010 datasets consist of a set of user queries relating to the "Title" field, the "Description" field and the "Narrative" field, a set of documents and Qrel files containing a list of relevant documents for a query. The experiment was conducted for English-Hindi CLIR to retrieve Hindi documents using English queries. In this paper, we used only the "Title" field of the queries. The test data collection is described in Table 2 as follows: We obtain results from two approaches, the first EHT approach English-Hindi CLIR using the Query field title and the second EHRT approach means English-Hindi CLIR using our approach. The results of both approaches are presented in terms of interpolation recall precision average in Table 3.

sections.heading: 4.1. Performance graph
sections.text: Table 2 shows that our English-Hindi CLIR performs better than the original English-Hindi CLIR title field queries in terms of MAP (average accuracy).

sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSION
sections.text: The obstacle in CLIR is poor performance compared to monolingual IR performance due to the query term inmatching, untranslated query words, multiple representations of query terms, etc. Considerable work is already being done in English-Hindi CLIR. Different approaches to retrieving information from the CLIR system are discussed in the related work part. These earlier suggested approaches have some advantages and disadvantages. In order to make these approaches more efficient and effective, the limitations of these approaches need to be further explored in order to improve the performance of the English-Hindi CLIR system. In this paper, we used transliteration of each query term to enable all possible combinations of Hindi queries without substituting the query position in order to improve the English-Hindi CLIR approach. referenceMentions.context: We are rapidly constructing the broad network architecture for transferring information across national barriers, but much remains to be done before linguistic boundaries can be better as effectively as geographic ones [1].
Because of big bang of on-line non-English webpage’s, CLIR systems have become progressively more important in recent years [2].

[3] in 1998 proposed a method for resolving ambiguity in query translation and phrasal translation by using statistics co-occurrence analysis from unlinked corpus and combines this technique with other techniques for resolving ambiguity and achieve more than 90% of CLIR performance while compared to the monolingual performance and also author compared their method with machine translation and parallel corpus techniques and they proved that good performance of retrieval can be achieved without the use of complex resources.

[4] in 2002 proposed a method to implicitly resolve ambiguities in Korean-English CLIR system using dynamic incremental clustering approach means the clusters are incrementally created for the top ranked documents for a particular query and next time when the same query will fired than the weight of each retrieved document is recalculated by using these clusters.

[5] in 2008 developed a disambiguation strategy for determining the correct translation for a given query by using novel graph based analysis of co-occurrence information and also developed a new approach to translate OOV (Out Of Vocabulary) terms means the words that are commonly not found in dictionary like, proper names, location, address etc.
[6] in 2010 investigated the influence of query expansion using WordNet in EnglishHindi CLIR system.
[7] in 2011 proposed an approach to build ontology from relational database with the help of some additional rules that can also be used for cross lingual information retrieval.
